feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Cold Weather Advisory issued November 30 at 3:48PM AKST until December 1 at 12:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Cold wind chill temperatures as low as 35 below, except to 15 below near Eaglecrest.
* WHERE...Along the Klondike Highway at higher elevations. Along the Haines Highway. Near downtown Juneau and along the road to Eaglecrest.
* WHEN...Until noon AKST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Hypothermia is possible if precautions are not taken.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Municipality of Skagway; Haines Borough and Klukwan; City and Borough of Juneau

cap:parameter.value: COLD WEATHER ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON AKST SUNDAY

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 30 at 4:46PM PST by NWS Elko NV
entry.summary:
Current visible and RGB composite satellite products as of 0415 PM PST indicate an area of widespread freezing fog continuing to persist across the Blackrock Desert in western Humboldt County. Impacts are being observed along SR-140 from near Denio Junction to Kings River/Desert Valley. Available surface observations in the area depict both surface tmeperatures and dewpoints in the mid to upper 20s. Main concern is for travelers along SR-140 who may encounter drastically reduced visibility and slick conditions due to ice accretion upon the highway. Additonal valley locations west of US-95 may observe patchy freezing fog beginning later tonight and thru tomorrow morning.
Visit www.weather.gov/elko for the latest weather information.

cap:parameter.value: Widespread and Patchy Freezing Fog West of US-95

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 30 at 2:50PM AKST until December 1 at 3:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...SNOW POTENTIAL CONTINUES THROUGH THIS WEEKEND...
Snow is forecast to develop to the south tonight and spread northward, lasting well into Sunday night. Accumulating snowfall will spread north with greatest accumulations along the Icy Strait corridor Saturday night. Snow will end as it begins, from south to north, with a transition to rain beginning over the southern outer coast Sunday morning.
* WHAT...Wet snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 1 to 3 inches. Snow changing to freezing rain Sunday morning. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.
* WHERE...Prince of Wales Island.
* WHEN...From 6 PM this evening to 3 AM AKST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slick and potentially hazardous travel conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow is expected to switch to freezing rain Sunday morning.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 6 PM THIS EVENING TO 3 AM AKST SUNDAY

entry.summary:
...SNOW POTENTIAL CONTINUES THROUGH THIS WEEKEND...
Snow is forecast to develop to the south tonight and spread northward, lasting well into Sunday night. Snow will end as it begins, from south to north, with a transition to rain beginning over the southern outer coast Sunday morning.
* WHAT...Heavy snow potential. Total snow accumulations of 5 to 7 inches possible. Winds gusting as high as 30 mph.
* WHERE...Petersburg Borough and Kake.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Greatest snowfall rates expected late Saturday night into Sunday morning before changing to rain.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; City and Borough of Wrangell

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued November 30 at 2:50PM AKST until December 2 at 3:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...SNOW POTENTIAL CONTINUES THROUGH THIS WEEKEND...
Snow is forecast to develop to the south tonight and spread northward, lasting well into Sunday night. Accumulating snowfall will spread north with greatest accumulations along the Icy Strait corridor Saturday night. Snow will end as it begins, from south to north, with a transition to rain beginning over the southern outer coast Sunday morning.

entry.title: Freeze Warning issued November 30 at 6:23PM EST until December 1 at 8:00AM EST by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures as low as 28 expected for inland southeast Georgia and the Suwannee Valley of northeast Florida. Localized Hard Freeze conditions possible.
* WHERE...Portions of northeast and northern Florida and southeast Georgia.
* WHEN...From 1 AM to 8 AM EST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Appropriate action should be taken to ensure tender vegetation and outdoor pets have adequate protection from the cold temperatures. Young children, the elderly and the homeless are especially vulnerable to the cold. Take measures to protect them.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Suwannee; Baker; Inland Nassau; Gilchrist; Eastern Hamilton; Western Hamilton; Northern Columbia; Southeastern Columbia; Southwestern Columbia; Coffee; Jeff Davis; Bacon; Appling; Wayne; Atkinson; Pierce; Brantley; Inland Glynn; Echols; Clinch; Inland Camden; Northern Ware; Northeastern Charlton; Southern Ware; Western Charlton

entry.title: Frost Advisory issued November 30 at 6:23PM EST until December 1 at 8:00AM EST by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Temperatures as low as 33 across coastal SE GA, and 35 for portions of northeast Florida will result in frost formation.
* WHERE...In Florida, Coastal Nassau, Western Putnam, Central Marion, and Western Marion Counties. In Georgia, Coastal Camden and Coastal Glynn Counties.
* WHEN...From 1 AM to 8 AM EST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Nassau; Western Putnam; Central Marion; Western Marion; Coastal Glynn; Coastal Camden

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 30 at 5:50PM EST by NWS Wilmington OH
entry.summary:
Light snow will pass across the area tonight. This will lead to some light accumulations, up to an inch for areas immediately along and south of the Ohio River with lesser amounts north of there.
Roadways, especially those that are untreated, may become snow covered and slick tonight. Motorists should be prepared for changing road conditions and exercise extra caution.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Franklin; Ripley; Dearborn; Ohio; Boone; Kenton; Campbell; Butler; Warren; Clinton; Hamilton; Clermont; Brown; Highland; Adams; Pike; Scioto

entry.title: Frost Advisory issued November 30 at 1:24PM PST until December 1 at 9:00AM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Freeze Warning, sub-freezing temperatures as low as 30 expected. For the Frost Advisory, temperatures as low as 34 will result in frost formation.
* WHERE...The Frost Advisory includes most areas of coastal Douglas and Coos County. The Freeze Warning includes Coos Bay, North Bend and portions of the inland Coquille Valley.
* WHEN...From 11 PM this evening to 9 AM PST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor plumbing.

entry.title: Air Stagnation Advisory issued November 30 at 1:24PM PST until December 4 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A ridge of high pressure will lead to a strong inversion and stagnant air conditions near the surface that will continue to trap pollutants. This could worsen air quality over time.
* WHERE...Valley locations across southern Oregon. West of the Cascades, this includes the Umpqua, Illinois, Applegate, and Rogue valleys. East of the Cascades, this includes Klamath Falls, Sprague River, Chiloquin, Chemult, Silver Lake, Paisley, and surrounding areas.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Poor air quality may cause issues for people with respiratory problems.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Douglas County; Eastern Curry County and Josephine County; Jackson County; Klamath Basin; Northern and Eastern Klamath County and Western Lake County; Central and Eastern Lake County

cap:parameter.value: AIR STAGNATION ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM PST WEDNESDAY

* WHERE...Central Brooks Range.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM AKST this evening.
* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 40 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued November 30 at 4:46PM AST until December 1 at 6:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Life-threatening rip currents due to breaking waves between 6 to 9 feet.
* WHERE...Beaches of the northern coast of Puerto Rico from Aguadilla to Ceiba. Beaches of Culebra and St. Croix.
* WHEN...Through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents that can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water where it becomes difficult to return to safety.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; Northeast; North Central; Northwest; Culebra; St Croix

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 30 at 2:20PM CST by NWS Duluth MN
entry.summary: Snow showers continue off of Lake Superior. These showers will ramp up tomorrow morning. Winds will turn northerly through the day allowing for snow accumulations to push further south into Iron County. The heaviest snow will be Sunday evening. An additional 5-7 inches will be possible across the north by Monday afternoon with lesser amounts as you head south. The light snow will accumulate on roads, bridges, and untreated surfaces. Expect slippery stretches on area roads and use caution if traveling.

cap:parameter.value: SNOW SHOWERS OFF OF LAKE SUPERIOR

entry.title: Freezing Fog Advisory issued November 30 at 12:05PM PST until December 1 at 11:00AM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:

* WHERE...For the Honey Lake Basin, Eagle Lake, Smoke Creek Desert, and areas around Pyramid Lake.
* WHEN...From 7 PM this evening to 11 AM PST Sunday.

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued November 30 at 12:02PM PST until December 2 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Increased threat of sneaker waves expected.
* WHERE...Coastal Del Norte, Northern Humboldt Coast, Southwestern Humboldt and Mendocino Coast Counties.
* WHEN...From 4 PM PST this afternoon through Monday afternoon. .
* IMPACTS...Large, unexpected waves can sweep across the beach without warning, sweeping people into the sea from rocks, jetties, and beaches. These sneaker waves can also move large objects such as logs, crushing anyone caught underneath.

* WHEN...Until 1 AM EST Monday.
* IMPACTS...This is a long duration event that will persist through the weekend impacting post holiday travel plans. Travel could be very difficult to impossible.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 30 at 2:43PM EST by NWS Morristown TN
entry.summary:
A weak system will move across southwest Virginia late tonight and early Sunday morning with increasing clouds and light precipitation. Light snow will develop, mainly across Wise and Russell Counties in Virginia, with snowfall of one-half inch or less is expected for most areas with up to 1 inch of snow possible across the highest elevations.
Slow down and use caution if traveling across the higher elevations of southwest Virginia late tonight and Sunday morning.

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued November 30 at 1:39PM EST until December 3 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 6 and 13 inches.
* WHERE...Cuyahoga and Geauga Counties.
* WHEN...From noon Sunday to 7 AM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. Whiteout conditions are expected and will make travel treacherous and potentially life-threatening. Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning and evening commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heaviest snowfall totals will be near the Cleveland Metro and east with a strong gradient tapering south and west across Cuyahoga County. Only 1 to 3 inches is possible across the southern and western portion of Cuyahoga County. Across Geauga County, the highest snowfall totals expected in the northern half of the county with 1 to 4 inches possible in the southern portion. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour will be possible under the heaviest squalls.

cap:parameter.value: LAKE EFFECT SNOW WARNING IN EFFECT FROM NOON SUNDAY TO 7 AM EST TUESDAY

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued November 30 at 1:39PM EST until December 3 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 6 inches today. An additional 10 to 20 inches is possible Sunday through Tuesday morning. This would bring the storm total snowfall for this event to 4 to 6 feet, with highest values across the northern portion of the county.
* WHERE...Northern Erie and Southern Erie Counties.
* WHEN...Until 7 AM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. Whiteout conditions are expected and will make travel treacherous and potentially life-threatening. Travel is impossible and should be postponed. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning and evening commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heavy lake effect snow is expected to continue into Tuesday with snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour. The highest accumulations are expected along the I-90 corridor and north with totals quickly decreasing to the south. There is a potential for a brief lull in snowfall this evening into the overnight hours as the heaviest band pushes north over Lake Erie before returning on Sunday. The warning will continue through this lull to account for the ongoing significant impacts and the likelihood of continued blowing snow. People should avoid travel unless absolutely necessary.

cap:parameter.value: LAKE EFFECT SNOW WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 AM EST TUESDAY

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued November 30 at 1:39PM EST until December 3 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 6 inches today. An additional 10 to 20 inches is possible Sunday through Tuesday morning. This would bring the storm total snowfall for this event to 4 to 5 feet.
* WHERE...Ashtabula Inland, Ashtabula Lakeshore, and Lake Counties.
* WHEN...Until 7 AM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. Whiteout conditions are expected and will make travel treacherous and potentially life-threatening. Travel is impossible and should be postponed. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning and evening commutes, especially along the I-90 corridor.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heavy lake effect snow is expected to continue into Tuesday morning with snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour. The highest accumulations are expected along the I-90 corridor and north with totals quickly decreasing to the south. There is a potential for a brief lull in snowfall this evening into the overnight hours as the heaviest band pushes north over Lake Erie before returning on Sunday. The warning will continue through this lull to account for the ongoing significant impacts and the likelihood of continued blowing snow.

cap:parameter.value: LAKE EFFECT SNOW WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 AM EST TUESDAY

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued November 30 at 1:39PM EST until December 3 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow possible. Total snow accumulations between 3 and 9 inches possible.
* WHERE...Crawford County.
* WHEN...From Sunday afternoon through Tuesday morning.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning and evening commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Winter Storm Watch for lake effect snow has been issued for Sunday through Tuesday morning to account for a second round of notable lake effect snowfall. The ongoing warning was not extended due to the expected lull in snowfall for nearly 24 hours. Motorists should still use caution, especially across the northern portion of the county where the most snow has already fallen and winds may result in blowing snow and locally reduced visibilities.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 30 at 1:15PM EST by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
Light to moderate snow will overspread southern portions of Central Indiana during the late afternoon hours and continue into tonight. Heaviest snowfall is expected in the evening hours near the US-50 corridor in South Central Indiana.
Total accumulations along a Terre Haute to Bloomington and Greensburg line are expected to be around an inch, with amounts tapering off rapidly north of that area. South of those areas, a Winter Weather Advisory is in effect from 3 PM this afternoon through 1 AM tonight for total amounts of 1 to as much as 3 inches of snow, with the highest amounts expected across far southwestern portions of the area, near Vincennes, Washington, and Shoals.
If traveling, slow down, drive carefully, and allow extra time to reach your destination.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Vigo; Clay; Owen; Monroe; Brown; Bartholomew; Decatur

cap:parameter.value: LIGHT ACCUMULATING SNOWFALL THIS AFTERNOON AND TONIGHT

* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE TONIGHT

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued November 30 at 7:00AM PST until December 1 at 1:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A high risk of sneaker waves is expected.
* WHERE...All beaches and shorelines of Douglas, Coos, and Curry counties.
* WHEN...From this evening through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping anyone caught underneath.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING THROUGH SUNDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: High Surf Warning issued November 30 at 3:38AM HST until November 30 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...HIGH SURF WARNING FOR NORTH AND WEST FACING SHORES OF NIIHAU KAUAI OAHU AND MOLOKAI... ...HIGH SURF WARNING FOR NORTH FACING SHORES OF MAUI... ...HIGH SURF WARNING FOR WEST FACING SHORES OF BIG ISLAND...
.Surf generated by an extra-large northwest swell (320 deg) will remain above warning levels through this afternoon.
* WHAT...Surf up to 30 feet for north facing shores of Kauai, Oahu, Molokai and Maui. Surf up to 18 to 24 feet for west facing shores of Kauai and Niihau, and 15 to 20 feet for west facing shores of Oahu and Molokai. Surf up to 12 feet for west facing shores of the Big Island
* WHERE...North and west facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, north facing shores of Maui, and west facing shores of the Big Island.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM HST this evening.
* IMPACTS...High. Expect very strong breaking waves and powerful currents. Waves breaking in channel entrances may make navigating the channels dangerous.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Niihau; Kauai Southwest; Waianae Coast; Oahu North Shore; Maui Windward West; Kona; Kohala; Kauai North; Koolau Windward; Molokai Windward; Molokai North; Molokai West; Windward Haleakala

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM HST THIS EVENING

entry.title: Flash Flood Watch issued November 30 at 6:05AM MST until December 2 at 6:00AM MST by NWS Grand Junction CO
entry.summary:
An ice jam release may cause a rapid increase in water levels and flow in the Roaring Fork River.
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by an ice jam is possible.
* WHERE...A portion of west central Colorado, including the following areas, Central Colorado River Basin and Gore and Elk Mountains/Central Mountain Valleys.
* WHEN...Through late Sunday night.
* IMPACTS...Anglers and anyone near or in the Roaring Fork River should use extreme caution and be on the lookout for ice and debris flowing in the river. Move away from the river and seek higher ground.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Water levels on the Roaring Fork River above Difficult Creek have risen 2 feet since colder temperatures arrived on Thanksgiving indicating a likely ice jam above this location. A minor release occurred Friday, but since then levels have risen further and another release is possible sometime today and/or Sunday. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Colorado River Basin; Gore and Elk Mountains/Central Mountain Valleys

cap:parameter.value: FLASH FLOOD WATCH FOR AN ICE JAM IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE SUNDAY NIGHT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 30 at 3:34AM EST by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
Light to moderate snow will overspread Central Indiana during the mid to late afternoon hours and continue into tonight. Heaviest snowfall is expected in the evening hours near the US-50 corridor in South Central Indiana.
Total accumulation is expected to range from less than an inch along the I-70 corridor to mainly 1-2 inches across southwestern and southern Indiana. Isolated accumulations near 3 inches are possible southwest of Bloomington where a Winter Weather Advisory has been issued.
If traveling, slow down, drive carefully, and allow extra time to reach your destination.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Vermillion; Parke; Putnam; Hendricks; Marion; Hancock; Henry; Vigo; Clay; Owen; Morgan; Johnson; Shelby; Rush; Sullivan; Greene; Monroe; Brown; Bartholomew; Decatur; Lawrence; Jackson; Jennings

cap:parameter.value: LIGHT ACCUMULATING SNOWFALL THIS AFTERNOON AND TONIGHT

entry.title: Avalanche Advisory issued November 27 at 3:17PM MST by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
SABCO
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.
...A SPECIAL AVALANCHE ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 4:30 PM WEDNESDAY UNTIL 4:30 PM SUNDAY...
*WHAT...Avalanche conditions are more dangerous than weve experienced this season. *WHERE...All mountainous areas in Colorado *WHEN... From 4:30 PM Wednesday until 4:30 PM Sunday. *IMPACTS... Backcountry travelers can easily trigger dangerous avalanches large enough to injure or kill a human. *PRECAUTION/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Avoid traveling on and under slopes with a slope angle steeper than about 30 degrees. You can trigger avalanches from a distance or from below. We will update the avalanche forecast each afternoon with more detailed information on local areas. Check it at www.colorado.gov/avalanche.
Davis
entry.cap:areaDesc: Elkhead and Park Mountains; Gore and Elk Mountains/Central Mountain Valleys; West Elk and Sawatch Mountains; Flat Tops; Northwestern San Juan Mountains; Southwest San Juan Mountains; West Jackson and West Grand Counties Above 9000 Feet; South and East Jackson/Larimer/North and Northeast Grand/Northwest Boulder Counties Above 9000 Feet; South and Southeast Grand/West Central and Southwest Boulder/Gilpin/Clear Creek/Summit/North and West Park Counties Above 9000 Feet; Larimer and Boulder Counties Between 6000 and 9000 Feet; Eastern Sawatch Mountains above 11000 Ft; Western Chaffee County Between 9000 and 11000 Ft; Eastern San Juan Mountains Above 10000 Ft
